docs.text: " dangerous beauty " is a really nothing more than a grandiose soap opera set in venice circa 1583 .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is beautifully filmed , wonderfully acted , and certainly nothing short of entertaining , but it lacks any true fundamental seriousness .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: dealing with themes of forbidden love , religious intolerance , subordination of women , sexual freedom , and the roles of pleasure and sin in a high-cultured society , it still feels like brightly lit fluff .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the director , marshall herskovitz , doesn't want to follow the dark and dangerous trail this story could lead down , so he opts for a more genial , livelier , and relatively shallow interpretation .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film takes place during the renaissance , a time when venice was the pleasure capital of europe .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: at this time , venice was its own republic , and it thrived on being the central juncture of east-west commerce .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film is told almost entirely through the viewpoint of the aristocracy and the bourgeoisie of venice , so we rarely get to see how the rest of the society lived .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: however , there is an abundance of detail concerning the lives and livelihoods of the upper classes , their hedonistic lifestyles and constant merriment .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the story centers on veronica franco ( catherine mccormack ) , a lower class woman who falls in love with marco venier ( rufus sewell ) , the son of wealthy aristocratic parents ( jeroen krabb ? and joanna cassidy ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: unfortunately , the culture of that time period did not view marriage as an act of love -- rather , it was more like a business transaction , where rich families married their sons and daughters to each other in order to secure power , wealth , and ensure that outsiders couldn't get in .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: veronica , despite her charm and good looks , is certainly an outsider .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: after a short love affair , marco breaks her heart with the news that he cannot marry her .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: however , because she is beautiful and intelligent , veronica has a chance to enter marco's world , albeit not as his wife .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: she decides to become a courtesan -- a class of women who were as well-educated as they were ravishing , and sold their sexuality to wealthy men for the privilege of wining and dining with the elite .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a courtesan was not a mere prostitute ; they were afforded a special place in society , and they were greatly revered , respected , and often envied .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: at one point , a character mentions that some rulers obtain more political advice from their courtesans than from their lieutenants .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: veronica goes through the transformation with the help of her mother , paola ( jacqueline bisset ) , who was once a famed courtesan herself .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: once she enters the lifestyle , veronica finds that it suits her quite well .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: she is allowed to read all the books she wants , she is given the opportunity to publish her poetry , and she has the richest and most powerful men in the republic throwing themselves at her feet , including the awestruck marco .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: their relationship develops into a playful bantering , with veronica utilizing her newfound power by constantly rejecting marco's advances .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in many ways , their relationship is sad because marco is married to a women he is unable to love , and veronica is consumed by multiple relationships with men she is unwilling to love .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " love the love , not the man , " as her mother told her .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " dangerous beauty , " which was based on a factual book by margaret rosenthal , flows along as smoothly and serenely as the grand canal running through the heart of venice .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it has multiple plot lines -- including veronica's adversarial relationship with a court poet ( oliver platt ) , her role in obtaining france's military assistance in venice's battle against the turks , and even the dreaded shadow of the plague and the encroachment of the spanish inquisition -- yet it is never confusing or overbearing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: much of the film's success is due to the glowing performance by catherine mccormack in the lead role .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: known chiefly for the small part she played as the lover whose murder raised mel gibson's ire in " braveheart " ( 1995 ) , mccormack shows the true gifts and inarguable talent of a leading lady .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: she has the kind of exquisite classical beauty that would be treasured in a courtesan ; her character is intelligent , witty , and both sensual and vulnerable , all of which mccormack easily transmits with a single flash of her eyes .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the rest of the roles are also filled well , including rufus sewell whose performance here and earlier this month in " dark city " have assured him a solid place in hollywood .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he has the same kind of unusual good looks and charm of ray liotta , and he seems perfectly at home in period dramas .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: oliver platt plays a variation of the comic relief role that he has come to inhabit like a second skin , although the film deals his character a cheap blow at the end by having him improbably join the inquisition and turn into the bad guy .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: platt is a good actor , but he's just too hard to hate .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: jacqueline bisset proves that she is every bit as stirring as she ever was , and even fred ward turns up in a small , but moving performance as marco's uncle .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " dangerous beauty " is marshall herskovitz's sophomore directorial effort , after the overlooked 1993 film " jack the bear . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: partnered with edward zwick , herskovitz has spent most of his time as a producer on television ( " thirtysomething , " " my so-called life " ) and in the movies ( " legends of the fall " ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his directing style can be best described as transparent -- it never gets in the way of the story , yet it has no discernible flourish or particular distinctions .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he could have approached the film in any number of ways , including overdosing on the sexual aspect , which he wisely avoids .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " dangerous beauty " contains just enough bare flesh and ribald sex to make it appropriately erotic , but not so much that it seems exploitative .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: herskovitz is also aided by a strong supporting crew , including the luscious photography by bojan bazelli , whose previous efforts include the highly-stylized thriller " kalifornia " ( 1993 ) and abel ferrara's dark sci-fi film " body snatchers " ( 1994 ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: bazelli captures the film in strong , bold colors , and be brings sixteenth-century venice to life in wide , panoramic shots that are often enhanced with digital imagery .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: however , the real details are found in the production design by norman garwood ( " brazil , " " the princess bride " ) and the costumes by gabriella pescucci ( " the age of innocence " ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only problem with " dangerous beauty " is that it doesn't stick with you .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's a good story well-told with interesting characters , but it's easy to shrug off once you've left the theater .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only sequence that has the chance to be truly indelible is veronica being pulled in front of the hypocrisy of the inquisition and threatened with the death penalty for her transgressions , but it never quite comes off because it's simply too melodramatic and conventional .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: herskovitz tries with all his might to make it a nailbiter , but somehow its outcome is a foregone conclusion , and like the rest of the film , it carries no real weight , despite the potential severity of the subject matter .
docs.label: positive
